Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story: I sat at my desk, headset resting around my neck, glancing at the clock. The call volume was unusually light today, and my supervisor had just sent a message reminding us that we could take our breaks whenever we wanted, as long as we logged them. My phone buzzed with a message from my cousin: “We’re starting the puja in an hour. Don’t be late!” My family had traveled across the state for this festival, and I knew how important it was to be present for every ritual, every offering. As a Hindu, participating fully in these ceremonies was not just expected—it was a way to honor my faith and my family. But as a telemarketer, I was supposed to stick to my scheduled hours, even if the rules were relaxed today. I felt the pressure mounting inside me, torn between the rare chance to be with my family for the festival and the responsibility to my job. My finger hovered over the “log break” button, my heart pounding as I weighed the expectations of my work against the pull of my faith.
